title: Jeremy's Unexpected Fracture
clinical_history: Jeremy, a 22-year-old college soccer player, presented to the clinic with swelling and pain in his right index finger. Two days ago, while practicing for a major tournament, he accidentally jammed his finger against a teammate's knee while trying to steal the ball. He noticed immediate pain and, in the hours following, swelling and bruising on the affected finger. Despite the discomfort, he completed the practice session by taping his finger to his index finger, falsely assuming it was a minor sprain. The following day, typing notes for his course, he found it frustratingly tender and decided to seek professional advice.
aggrevating_factors: any attempt to grip objects, typing, and movement of the finger joint
easing_factors: rest, application of ice, and keeping the finger immobilized
past_history: No significant injuries to the hands previously. History of multiple ankle sprains due to playing sports.
medical_history: No known allergies, up-to-date on vaccinations, and no significant medical conditions.
medications: Occasionally takes ibuprofen for minor aches from sports activities
personal_history: Active college student majoring in Physical Education. Lives in an apartment nearby the university with three of his teammates. Engages regularly in competitive sports.
imaging: X-ray revealing a non-displaced fracture of the proximal phalanx of the right index finger
